goals.question: What is the distribution of salaries across different job categories?
goals.visualization: Box plot of salary vs job category
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range, median, and outliers of salaries across different job categories.

goals.question: What is the trend of job openings over time?
goals.visualization: Line chart of job openings vs time
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there are any seasonal trends or changes in job openings over time.

goals.question: What is the most common job category in the dataset?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of job category vs count
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us identify the most common job category in the dataset and its frequency.

goals.question: What is the distribution of required education level for different job categories?
goals.visualization: Stacked bar chart of job category vs education level
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the education requirements for different job categories and their distribution.

goals.question: What is the correlation between years of experience and salary?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of years of experience vs salary
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the relationship between years of experience and salary and if there is any correlation between the two variables.

code:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
    sns.boxplot(x='job_category', y='salary', data=data)
    plt.title('What is the distribution of salaries across different job categories?', wrap=True)
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.xlabel('Job Category')
    plt.ylabel('Salary')
    plt.legend(title='Job Categories', loc='upper right', labels=data['job_category'].unique())
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], errors='coerce')
    data = data[pd.notna(data['date'])]
    
    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
    sns.lineplot(x='date', y='job_openings', data=data)
    plt.title('What is the trend of job openings over time?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Time')
    plt.ylabel('Job Openings')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.legend(['Job Openings'])
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    job_counts = data['job_category'].value_counts()
    sns.barplot(x=job_counts.index, y=job_counts.values)
    plt.xlabel('Job Category')
    plt.ylabel('Count')
    plt.title('What is the most common job category in the dataset?', wrap=True)
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.legend(title='Job Categories', labels=job_counts.index, loc='upper right')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data = data.groupby(['job_category', 'education_level']).size().unstack().fillna(0)
    data = data.div(data.sum(axis=1), axis=0)
    ax = data.plot(kind='bar', stacked=True, figsize=(10, 6))
    plt.title("What is the distribution of required education level for different job categories?", wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel("Job Category")
    plt.ylabel("Percentage of Education Level")
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.legend(title="Education Level", loc="upper left")
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.scatterplot(data=data, x='years_of_experience', y='salary')
    plt.title('What is the correlation between years of experience and salary?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
